cln_elements.content:
As tabulated in (), the conductivity values at 65% humidity and at 30 °C are 3.94 × 10–7 S/cm for Ni-MOF and 1.69 × 10–7 S/cm for Co-MOF. It is well-known fact that the conductivity values are linearly proportional to temperatures and relative humidity. The mutual influences could be rationalized in terms of external supply of charge carrier protons (from water vapor) and their thermally induced enhanced transportation across the system. Naturally, we carry out conductivity measurements at various temperature and humidity. For a systematic study of their mutual interplay, we kept the sample at a fixed humidity and measure the conductivity values at different temperatures, and then repeat the variable-temperature measurements at different fixed humidity (65%, 80% and 95%). As expected, the conductivity values of both the MOFs increases with increasing the relative humidity (, ). Furthermore, with increasing temperature conductivity show a upward trend while the best values for both the systems are obtained as 1.95 × 10–3 S cm–1 and 5.79 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 95% humidity and 85 °C for Ni-MOF and Co-MOF respectively.

As illustrated in , most of the Nyquist plots exhibit an imperfect arc, which prompts us to consider the intercept at the z′ axis as the resistance of the material for proton conduction.

The resultant resistance values were found to follow a decreasing trend from 1.18 × 103 Ω to 65Ω for Ni-MOF and 2.70 × 104 Ω to 219 Ω for Co-MOF, as the temperature was increased from 303 to 358 K at 95% RH. This indicates the improvement of proton conductivity with an increase in temperature due to the thermal activation of charge carriers or protons.

Magnetic MOFs

The above results are in good agreement with our assumption that electrical properties can be imparted and improved through molecular engineering of ligands during synthesis of a MOF. Of particular interest was the syn-anti bridging mode of carboxylate groups that are situated in tandem with the chelating coordination of the carboxylate and ortho-oriented sulfonic moiety in Co-MOF (). From a magnetic point view, such coordination modes are of significant importance. Naturally, we shift our focus toward the second objectives of magnetic properties to fully justify the notion of generating an integrated system showing mutually inclusive electrical and magnetic properties. It is worth mentioning here that crystalline phase purity of the MOFs was verified by powder diffraction patterns before magnetic data collection. The variable temperature direct current (DC) magnetic susceptibility data were collected with the crushed microcrystalline samples in the temperature range between 2 and 300 K, with an applied magnetic field of 0.1 T. The χm T (χm is the molar magnetic susceptibility) vs T plots for Co-MOF (a) give the χm T value of 8.67 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K, for three Co-centers, which is much higher than the expected spin-only value of three noninteracting Co­(II) centers is 5.625 cm3 mol–1 K (S = 3/2, g = 2.0); this is due to the orbital contribution arising from each Co­(II) center. The χm T value decreases with decreasing temperature, and after 100 K it sharply falls; with further cooling, the value decreases smoothly and finally reaches a value of 5.16 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. The behavior closely resembles to the antiferromagnetic interaction between the neighboring metal ions. Using the Curie–Weiss equation (b), data were fitted. From the curve of 1/χm vs T, the Curie–Weiss law 1/χm= (T – θ)/C gives the results for C = 8.77 cm3 mol–1 K and θ = −10.87 K. The negative θ for Co-MOF demonstrates antiferromagnetic interactions between adjacent Co­(II) centers. Similar experimental measurements were carried out for Ni-MOF. The χm T versus T plots for Ni-MOF reveal the χm T value of 6.40 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K, for four Ni­(II) centers which is greater than the theoretical spin only value of four noninteracting Ni centers 4 cm3 mol–1 K (S = 1, g = 2.0); this is also due to antiferromagnetic interactions between four Ni­(II) centers at room temperature (e). With decreasing the temperature, the χm T value initially decreases slightly until it reaches 5.53 cm3 mol–1 K at 15 K. Subsequent cooling of the sample slightly increases the χm T value, and it reaches 5.62 cm3 mol–1 K at 9 K. On further cooling, it falls sharply and finally gives the value of 4.26 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. These types of phenomena indicate the ferromagnetic interactions at low temperature. These data also follow the Curie–Weiss law with C = 12.76 cm3 mol–1 K and θ = −7.91 K (f). The result clearly hints at antiferromagnetic interactions between the adjacent Ni­(II) ions at higher temperature.

In between the temperature range of 8–13 K from 0 to 5 T isothermal magnetization (M vs H) for Co-MOF was plotted, from which it was observed that the plot does not saturate even at the highest field of 5 T (c). The maximum magnetic moment value was 21.4 emu/g obtained at 8 K. To examine the anisotropy of the system, the magnetic moment was plotted against H/T for 8–13 K, and this shows that all of the isotherms do not fall on the same master plot, which clearly reveals the existence of anisotropy of Co-MOF (d). Further, if we carefully noticed the geometry around the Co center which is bound with the H2MDP in the structure of the Co-MOF it will be observed that there is distortion in the Oh geometry, which may result in magnetic anisotropy for slow relaxation of magnetization. It sparks interest to look for the possibility of slow magnetic relaxation for the Co-MOF. This prompted us to measure AC susceptibility data to evaluate the SMM potential of the Co-MOF. Ni-MOF, however, did not show any significant peak for SMM.

Frequency dependency in-phase (χ M′) and out-of-phase (χ M″) AC susceptibility plots were also examined. The SMM behavior of the sample (c,d) was confirmed by the lack of merging of the plots. ln­(ω) was plotted versus 1/T and fitted using the Arrhenius equation: ln­(ω) = ln­(1/τ0) – (E eff/kT) (), where ω is the frequency, (ω = 1/τ)­τ0 is the relaxation time, and E eff is the energy barrier to estimate the relaxation time and energy barrier of Co-MOF. From the fitting, the energy barrier (E/k) = 34(5) K and the relaxation time (τ0) = 3.5 × 10–8 s. The relaxation time is in the range of an SMM. The spin disorder parameter (ϕ) calculated using the equation ϕ = (ΔT P/T P)/(log υ) (υ denotes the frequency used in AC measurement) for Co-MOF is 0.22 (Figure S14), which is greater than 0.1 and belongs to a normal value for a super-paramagnet (ϕ > 0.1), and hence Co-MOF can be considered as an SMM, ruling out the possibility of a spin glass state (ϕ ≈ 0.01).

The Co-MOF shows an excellent light-dependent diode with ideality factors of 0.78 (in dark) and 0.92 (in the presence of light), while the corresponding conductivity values are 9.09 × 10–5 S/m (dark) 6.31 × 10–4 S/m (light). Ni-MOF, on the other hand, shows a light-independent ideality factor of 1.06 and a conductivity value of 1.80 × 10–4 S/m when it is used as a Schottky barrier diode. Furthermore, both the MOFs show excellent proton conductivity. The free sulfonic acid moiety present inside the network of Ni-MOF acts as a proton carrier facilitator and shows a high proton conductivity value of 1.95× 10–3 S/cm at 95% relative humidity and 85 °C. The Co-MOF, on the other hand, shows an impressive proton conductivity value of 5.80 × 10–4 S/cm at 95% relative humidity and 85 °C, resulting from an inherent extensive H-bonded water cluster residing inside the porous network. Both the MOFs show remarkable mutually inclusive electrical-magnetic properties which can be used for fabricating magnetic storage memory devices or conductivity-based electrical devices like rectifier, logic gates, and membranes for fuel cells.
cln_elements.clean_text:
As tabulated in (), the conductivity values at 65% humidity and at 30 °C are 3.94 × 10-7 S/cm for Ni-MOF and 1.69 × 10-7 S/cm for Co-MOF. It is well-known fact that the conductivity values are linearly proportional to temperatures and relative humidity. The mutual influences could be rationalized in terms of external supply of charge carrier protons (from water vapor) and their thermally induced enhanced transportation across the system. Naturally, we carry out conductivity measurements at various temperature and humidity. For a systematic study of their mutual interplay, we kept the sample at a fixed humidity and measure the conductivity values at different temperatures, and then repeat the variable-temperature measurements at different fixed humidity (65%, 80% and 95%). As expected, the conductivity values of both the MOFs increases with increasing the relative humidity (, ). Furthermore, with increasing temperature conductivity show a upward trend while the best values for both the systems are obtained as 1.95 × 10-3 S cm-1 and 5.79 × 10-4 S cm-1 at 95% humidity and 85 °C for Ni-MOF and Co-MOF respectively.

As illustrated in , most of the Nyquist plots exhibit an imperfect arc, which prompts us to consider the intercept at the z' axis as the resistance of the material for proton conduction.

The resultant resistance values were found to follow a decreasing trend from 1.18 × 103 Ω to 65Ω for Ni-MOF and 2.70 × 104 Ω to 219 Ω for Co-MOF, as the temperature was increased from 303 to 358 K at 95% RH. This indicates the improvement of proton conductivity with an increase in temperature due to the thermal activation of charge carriers or protons.

Magnetic MOFs

The above results are in good agreement with our assumption that electrical properties can be imparted and improved through molecular engineering of ligands during synthesis of a MOF. Of particular interest was the syn-anti bridging mode of carboxylate groups that are situated in tandem with the chelating coordination of the carboxylate and ortho-oriented sulfonic moiety in Co-MOF (). From a magnetic point view, such coordination modes are of significant importance. Naturally, we shift our focus toward the second objectives of magnetic properties to fully justify the notion of generating an integrated system showing mutually inclusive electrical and magnetic properties. It is worth mentioning here that crystalline phase purity of the MOFs was verified by powder diffraction patterns before magnetic data collection. The variable temperature direct current (DC) magnetic susceptibility data were collected with the crushed microcrystalline samples in the temperature range between 2 and 300 K, with an applied magnetic field of 0.1 T. The χm T (χm is the molar magnetic susceptibility) vs T plots for Co-MOF (a) give the χm T value of 8.67 cm3 mol-1 K at 300 K, for three Co-centers, which is much higher than the expected spin-only value of three noninteracting Co(II) centers is 5.625 cm3 mol-1 K (S = 3/2, g = 2.0); this is due to the orbital contribution arising from each Co(II) center. The χm T value decreases with decreasing temperature, and after 100 K it sharply falls; with further cooling, the value decreases smoothly and finally reaches a value of 5.16 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. The behavior closely resembles to the antiferromagnetic interaction between the neighboring metal ions. Using the Curie-Weiss equation (b), data were fitted. From the curve of 1/χm vs T, the Curie-Weiss law 1/χm= (T - θ)/C gives the results for C = 8.77 cm3 mol-1 K and θ = -10.87 K. The negative θ for Co-MOF demonstrates antiferromagnetic interactions between adjacent Co(II) centers. Similar experimental measurements were carried out for Ni-MOF. The χm T versus T plots for Ni-MOF reveal the χm T value of 6.40 cm3 mol-1 K at 300 K, for four Ni(II) centers which is greater than the theoretical spin only value of four noninteracting Ni centers 4 cm3 mol-1 K (S = 1, g = 2.0); this is also due to antiferromagnetic interactions between four Ni(II) centers at room temperature (e). With decreasing the temperature, the χm T value initially decreases slightly until it reaches 5.53 cm3 mol-1 K at 15 K. Subsequent cooling of the sample slightly increases the χm T value, and it reaches 5.62 cm3 mol-1 K at 9 K. On further cooling, it falls sharply and finally gives the value of 4.26 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. These types of phenomena indicate the ferromagnetic interactions at low temperature. These data also follow the Curie-Weiss law with C = 12.76 cm3 mol-1 K and θ = -7.91 K (f). The result clearly hints at antiferromagnetic interactions between the adjacent Ni(II) ions at higher temperature.
